articles.headline: Amid G.O.P. Din, Santorum Wages Struggle to Be Heard
articles.snippet: Rick Santorum has taken the offensive against rival social conservative candidates in the Republican presidential field.
articles.abstract: Rick Santorum has taken the offensive against rival social conservative candidates in the Republican presidential field.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANDERSON, S.C. — There was little fanfare and almost no entourage when Rick Santorum, a Republican candidate for president, rolled up to the Chick-fil-A on Clemson Boulevard here the other day.

articles.headline: Investor Fear Over Morgan Stanley Sharpens
articles.snippet: Investors are worried about the bank’s exposure to the European debt crisis and its reliance on short-term borrowing to finance its operations.
articles.abstract: Investors are worried about the bank’s exposure to the European debt crisis and its reliance on short-term borrowing to finance its operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is Morgan Stanley’s turn on the hot seat.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Remedy Is Elusive as Metallic Hips Fail at a Fast Rate
articles.snippet: As greater numbers of a popular hip implant are beginning to fail, doctors and patients are grappling with how to detect and repair the potential damage.
articles.abstract: As greater numbers of a popular hip implant are beginning to fail, doctors and patients are grappling with how to detect and repair the potential damage.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — As surgeons here sliced through tissue surrounding a failed artificial hip in a 53-year-old man, they discovered what looked like a biological dead zone. There were matted strands of tissue stained gray and black; a large strip of muscle near the hip no longer contracted.

articles.headline: The Political Pulpit
articles.snippet: This weekend, hundreds of ministers will speak up for presidential candidates they favor, flouting a law that prohibits tax-exempt organizations from campaigning on political issues.
articles.abstract: This weekend, hundreds of ministers will speak up for presidential candidates they favor, flouting a law that prohibits tax-exempt organizations from campaigning on political issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: This weekend, hundreds of pastors, including some of the nation’s evangelical leaders, will climb into their pulpits to preach about American politics, flouting a decades-old law that prohibits tax-exempt churches and other charities from campaigning on election issues.

articles.headline: Strike Reflects U.S. Shift to Drones in Terror Fight
articles.snippet: Huge costs and uncertain outcomes in two wars have led the United States to embrace drones, like those used in the strike that killed Anwar al-Awlaki, in the fight against terrorism.
articles.abstract: Huge costs and uncertain outcomes in two wars have led the United States to embrace drones, like those used in the strike that killed Anwar al-Awlaki, in the fight against terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The C.I.A. drone strike that killed Anwar al-Awlaki, the American-born propagandist for Al Qaeda’s rising franchise in Yemen, was one more demonstration of what American officials describe as a cheap, safe and precise tool to eliminate enemies. It was also a sign that the decade-old American campaign against terrorism has reached a turning point.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: On the Road to Detroit’s Big Pileup
articles.snippet: A G.M.-Ford merger? That’s how desperate Detroit’s auto industry was in the summer of 2008, according to “Once Upon a Car,” a new book by Bill Vlasic.
articles.abstract: A G.M.-Ford merger? That’s how desperate Detroit’s auto industry was in the summer of 2008, according to “Once Upon a Car,” a new book by Bill Vlasic.
articles.lead_paragraph: If General Motors were any other company, it would probably be dead by now. In the summer of 2008, nearly a year before G.M. filed for bankruptcy, its executives were growing desperate. Rick Wagoner, its chief executive, secretly proposed a merger with Ford, while Bill Ford courted the future president, Barack Obama, in an attempt to safeguard his company. This article is adapted from “Once Upon a Car: The Fall and Resurrection of America’s Big Three Automakers — G.M., Ford and Chrysler” by Bill Vlasic, the Detroit bureau chief of The New York Times. The book, to be published Tuesday by William Morrow, reveals new details of the chaos at the Big Three. Conversations recounted in the book were based on more than 100 interviews.

articles.headline: The Bank Case That Refuses to Die
articles.snippet: A judge ruled that the government should pay $205 million in damages for Carteret Savings Bank’s failure. But the Justice Department won’t let the case go.
articles.abstract: A judge ruled that the government should pay $205 million in damages for Carteret Savings Bank’s failure. But the Justice Department won’t let the case go.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANGELO R. MOZILO and Kerry K. Killinger look like they’re in the clear: federal prosecutors have declined to go after them and many other masters of the mortgage disaster.

articles.headline: Christie Team Assessing How Fast a 2012 Campaign Could Be Mounted
articles.snippet: In the wake of a relentless courtship by Republicans, advisers to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey are considering whether they could set up effective political operations in Iowa and New Hampshire.
articles.abstract: In the wake of a relentless courtship by Republicans, advisers to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey are considering whether they could set up effective political operations in Iowa and New Hampshire.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chris Christie’s political advisers are working to determine whether they could move fast enough to set up effective political operations in Iowa and New Hampshire in the wake of a relentless courtship aimed at persuading Mr. Christie, the governor of New Jersey, to plunge into the race for the Republican presidential nomination, according to operatives briefed on the preparations.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, David M. Halbfinger and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Profits, but No Joy, for Merrill
articles.snippet: Merrill Lynch was a weight when it first collapsed into the arms of Bank of America in 2008. Now the tables have turned.
articles.abstract: Merrill Lynch was a weight when it first collapsed into the arms of Bank of America in 2008. Now the tables have turned.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT sounded like a crank call, the business equivalent of “Do you have Prince Albert in a can?”: Hello, Warren Buffett wants to talk to your boss.

articles.headline: Seeking Taxes, Romney Went After Business
articles.snippet: The Romney administration scoured the tax code for loopholes, extracting millions of corporate dollars to help close budget gaps.
articles.abstract: The Romney administration scoured the tax code for loopholes, extracting millions of corporate dollars to help close budget gaps.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Much of the business community in Massachusetts was puzzled. Mitt Romney, a Republican with high-caliber corporate credentials, had run for governor pledging to sweep aside barriers to business and act as the state’s “top salesman.”

articles.headline: Key Syrian City Takes On the Tone of a Civil War
articles.snippet: Across the political spectrum, residents of Homs, Syria, speak of a recent shift, from a largely peaceful uprising to a struggle that has made the city violent, fearful and determined.
articles.abstract: Across the political spectrum, residents of Homs, Syria, speak of a recent shift, from a largely peaceful uprising to a struggle that has made the city violent, fearful and determined.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by a correspondent for The New York Times in Homs, Syria, and written by  Anthony Shadid in Beirut, Lebanon.

articles.headline: Coupon Sites Are a Great Deal, but Not Always to Merchants
articles.snippet: Some entrepreneurs question the usefulness of pitting customers seeking deals against merchants hoping for loyalty.
articles.abstract: Some entrepreneurs question the usefulness of pitting customers seeking deals against merchants hoping for loyalty.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like businesses across the land, the Madison Avenue spa Wellpath tried to drum up customers by running heavily discounted coupons on deal-of-the-day Web sites. But the Internet coupon fad is shrinking faster than fat from a weight-loss laser.

articles.headline: In Debt Talks, Divide on What Tax Breaks Are Worth Keeping
articles.snippet: Talk of cutting tax breaks to raise money and reduce the debt has become a mantra in Washington, but it threatens a favorite political tool of lawmakers on both sides of the aisle.
articles.abstract: Talk of cutting tax breaks to raise money and reduce the debt has become a mantra in Washington, but it threatens a favorite political tool of lawmakers on both sides of the aisle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Plenty of lawmakers are against tax breaks and so-called loopholes. Unless, of course, they personally helped create them.
articles.byline: By Ron Nixon and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Online Tools Help Bands Do Business
articles.snippet: Topspin Media and other companies are offering bands sophisticated tools to run all aspects of their online business, including direct-to-fan ticket sales.
articles.abstract: Topspin Media and other companies are offering bands sophisticated tools to run all aspects of their online business, including direct-to-fan ticket sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Pixies, the reunited stars of 1980s alt-rock, decided recently to play a special show in Los Angeles, they wanted to make sure their biggest local followers were invited first.

articles.headline: A U.S.-Backed Geothermal Plant in Nevada Struggles
articles.snippet: Like Solyndra, the now-famous California solar company, Nevada Geothermal Power is facing financial trouble after encountering problems at its only operating plant.
articles.abstract: Like Solyndra, the now-famous California solar company, Nevada Geothermal Power is facing financial trouble after encountering problems at its only operating plant.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a remote desert spot in northern Nevada, there is a geothermal plant run by a politically connected clean energy start-up that has relied heavily on an Obama administration loan guarantee and is now facing financial turmoil.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Social Media News Site Gains Clout
articles.snippet: Mashable, a news Web site focusing on the world of digital culture and social media, is becoming an attractive place for advertisers.
articles.abstract: Mashable, a news Web site focusing on the world of digital culture and social media, is becoming an attractive place for advertisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pete Cashmore acknowledged he was nervous. Only a few years ago, he was living with his parents in a small town in northeast Scotland, trying to start a technology blog. Now, at 26, he was about to interview Elie Wiesel, the 82-year-old Holocaust survivor and Nobel Peace Prize winner, onstage at the 92nd Street Y, about the future of ethics in a digitally connected world.

articles.headline: Animated Fruit With Ambition
articles.snippet: The “Annoying Orange” has embarked on the road to television, a path littered with the carcasses of other Internet standouts.
articles.abstract: The “Annoying Orange” has embarked on the road to television, a path littered with the carcasses of other Internet standouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — There is little doubt that Dane Boedigheimer has created an online sensation that struck a pop cultural nerve. The “Annoying Orange” Web videos that he’s been rolling out for the last two years have racked up more than 800 million views on You Tube, where the threshold for a runaway hit is about 50 million.

articles.headline: Oracle Convention Engulfs San Francisco With a Party Atmosphere
articles.snippet: Oracle’s technology for storing and managing data is at the heart of the modern business world, and its annual event draws 45,000 people, and their expense accounts.
articles.abstract: Oracle’s technology for storing and managing data is at the heart of the modern business world, and its annual event draws 45,000 people, and their expense accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Commuters driving into this city on Monday morning will discover major downtown thoroughfares closed. More than 129,000 square feet of tents will have sprouted around the city’s convention center, where 4.25 miles of power cables, 300 miles of phone and Internet wires and enough beer trucks to sate 45,000 people are in place.

articles.headline: Snag for Perry: Offensive Name at Texas Camp
articles.snippet: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas found himself on the defensive on Sunday over a report that he had hunted at a camp with a racially charged name that his father, and later Mr. Perry, had leased.
articles.abstract: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas found himself on the defensive on Sunday over a report that he had hunted at a camp with a racially charged name that his father, and later Mr. Perry, had leased.
articles.lead_paragraph: The campaign of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas found itself on the defensive on Sunday over a report that he had hunted at and taken guests to a West Texas camp with a racially charged name that his father, and later Mr. Perry, had leased.

articles.headline: Americans Raid Byways of Haqqani Insurgents in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The Pentagon plans to pull most forces from Afghanistan by 2014. As they try to prepare for that exit, American units are focusing on the Haqqani insurgent network.
articles.abstract: The Pentagon plans to pull most forces from Afghanistan by 2014. As they try to prepare for that exit, American units are focusing on the Haqqani insurgent network.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARBARAN, Afghanistan — The first helicopter landed in the bluish gray gloom before dawn. More than 20 members of an American reconnaissance platoon and Afghan troops accompanying them jogged out through the swirling dust, moving into a forest smelling of sage and pine.

articles.headline: New State Rules Raising Hurdles at Voting Booth
articles.snippet: Republicans say they want to prevent voter fraud, but some groups say they worry that the new restrictions may discourage people from going to vote.
articles.abstract: Republicans say they want to prevent voter fraud, but some groups say they worry that the new restrictions may discourage people from going to vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Republicans won control of many statehouses last November, more than a dozen states have passed laws requiring voters to show photo identification at polls, cutting back early voting periods or imposing new restrictions on voter registration drives.

articles.headline: Crossing Over, and Over
articles.snippet: Migrant shelters along the Mexican border are filled with seasoned crossers braving ever-greater risks to get back to their families in the United States — the country they consider home.
articles.abstract: Migrant shelters along the Mexican border are filled with seasoned crossers braving ever-greater risks to get back to their families in the United States — the country they consider home.
articles.lead_paragraph: AGUA PRIETA, Mexico — "My wife, my son — I have to get back to them," Daniel kept telling himself, from the moment he was arrested in Seattle for driving with an expired license, all the way through the deportation proceeding that delivered him to Mexico in June.

articles.headline: Wall Street Approaches a Bear Market
articles.snippet: Shares in every major sector spiraled downward on Monday amid anxiety over the European debt crisis and the struggling United States economy.
articles.abstract: Shares in every major sector spiraled downward on Monday amid anxiety over the European debt crisis and the struggling United States economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once again, fits of optimism in the markets are being overwhelmed by forces of gloom.
articles.byline: By Joshua Brustein and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Amanda Knox Freed After Appeal in Italian Court
articles.snippet: An appeals court overturned the homicide convictions of the American Amanda Knox and a co-defendant and ordered them freed, ending a sensational trial.
articles.abstract: An appeals court overturned the homicide convictions of the American Amanda Knox and a co-defendant and ordered them freed, ending a sensational trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: PERUGIA, Italy — With a rapt worldwide television audience looking on, an Italian court on Monday reversed the murder conviction of 24-year-old Amanda Knox, the American student whose sensational murder trial had reverberated on both sides of the Atlantic.
